casebody.data:
UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff-Appellee, v. Jose Maria BUITRON-GARCIA, Defendant-Appellant. No. 03-51241

Conference Calendar.

United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit. June 23, 2004. Joseph H. Gay, Jr, Assistant U.S. Attorney, San Antonio, TX, U.S. Attorney’s Office, Western District of Texas, for Plaintiff-Appellee. *534Luden B. Campbell, Federal Public Defender, Henry Joseph Bemporad, San Antonio, TX, David B. Fannin, Federal Public Defender’s Office, Western District of Texas, Alpine, TX, for Defendant-Appellant. Before BARKSDALE, DeMOSS, and CLEMENT, Circuit Judges. PER CURIAM: *

Jose Maria Buitron-Garcia appeals his guilty plea conviction for possession with intent to distribute 100 kilograms or more, but not less than 1,000 kilograms, of marihuana. He argues that the sentencing provision of 21 U.S.C. § 841(b)(1)(B) is unconstitutional in light of Apprendi v. New Jersey, 530 U.S. 466, 490, 120 S.Ct. 2348, 147 L.Ed.2d 435 (2000). BuitronGarcia concedes that his argument is foreclosed by our opinion in United States v. Slaughter, 238 F.3d 580, 581-82 (5th Cir. 2000). He raises the issue only to preserve it for Supreme Court review.

A panel of this court cannot overrule a prior panel’s decision in the absence of an intervening contrary or superseding decision by this court sitting en banc or by the United States Supreme Court. Burge v. Parish of St. Tammany, 187 F.3d 452, 466 (5th Cir.1999). No such decision overruling Slaughter exists. Accordingly, Buitron-Gareia’s argument is foreclosed, and the judgment of the district court is AFFIRMED.

The Government has moved for a summary affirmance in lieu of filing an appellee’s brief. In its motion, the Government asks that an appellee’s brief not be required. The motion is GRANTED.

AFFIRMED; MOTION GRANTED.

Pursuant to 5th Cir. R. 47.5, the court has determined that this opinion should not be published and is not precedent except under the limited circumstances set forth in 5th Cir. R. 47.5.4.
